paper.title: Phase-curve Evidence for an Atmosphere on TRAPPIST-1 b

core_question: Does the Earth-sized rocky exoplanet TRAPPIST-1 b retain an atmosphere, as inferred from JWST MIRI thermal phase-curve spectroscopy and the 15 um CO2 band?

datasets_or_cohorts.label: JWST MIRI phase-curve spectroscopy
datasets_or_cohorts.sample_size_or_observations: Phase-resolved thermal spectra over an orbital phase curve (TRAPPIST-1 b)
datasets_or_cohorts.description: JWST MIRI low-resolution spectroscopy measuring the thermal phase variation and spectral structure around the 15 um CO2 band for TRAPPIST-1 b.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Bare-rock (no atmosphere) null scenario
datasets_or_cohorts.sample_size_or_observations: Model baseline: no-atmosphere limit with minimal heat redistribution
datasets_or_cohorts.description: A comparison model representing an atmosphere-free, bare-rock planet with near-zero day-night heat transport, used as the null hypothesis in retrieval comparisons.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: CO2-rich atmosphere retrieval family
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Atmosphere model family with significant greenhouse-gas absorption, evaluated against phase-curve thermal variation and the 15 um CO2 spectral region.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: O2-rich atmosphere scenario
datasets_or_cohorts.description: An oxidized composition scenario that can produce weaker CO2 signature constraints, explored as an alternative atmosphere-bearing interpretation.

major_limitations: Single-planet study; does not establish prevalence across M-dwarf rocky planets.
Retrieval assumptions (circulation, opacity priors, clouds) affect quantitative posteriors.
Stellar variability and instrument systematics can bias weak spectral features.
Night-side constraints are weaker than day-side constraints in the current dataset.
